Message.Title: Gray is dead, long live Gray
Message.Msg: when gray was announced in nvda's roadmap, I said that's a dead chip, too little too late, a Tegra 3 with radio at end of 2013 is just way too late. Evidently now nvda agrees with me, after god knows how many millions of R&D $ down the drain: "In order for us to really gain a larger footprint in smartphones, we have to integrate 4G LTE modem into our application processor. This is a brand-new market for us. Although we are already shipping some quantities of discrete LTE modems, the vast majority of the marketplace is really integrated. And so our -- we have a next-generation application processor integrated with a next-generation LTE. And this quarter, we hope to tape out and race it to market." the original gray is dead, now it will be done with T4 and not T3

Topic.Title: "Project Denver going great!" says Jen Hsun Huang

Message.Msg: The 64-bit Project Denver is meant to compete in the server market. Given the reality of PC extinction followed by servers in just matter of few years I cannot see how Project Denver can be a profitable endeavour to Nvidia. The server markets are rapidly declining due to consolidations by being replaced by “cloud server architecture” where customers prefer to rent spaces rather than owning their own. By the time P. Denver goes into production there won’t be nearly enough customers left to recuperate Nvidia's R&D costs. Besides, Intel is currently heading towards a highly energy efficient chip called Atom Gemini that is also targeting the server markets and is heavily favored by the industry such as HP, Dell, and IBM, so ARM based 64-bit processors will ended up being disadvantaged again. This is because most costs associated with the change of architecture (i.e. from x86 to ARM) is with their application migrations, re-coding, and porting. Unlike with consumer devices such as smartphones and tablets a long lasting battery will not be an issue with servers (wall plugged) but "computing power" will definitely be.

Topic.Title: Gray is dead, long live Gray

Message.Msg: Not just a LTE incorporated SoC but a multi-band / multi-protocol that supports a minimum of 12 bands (domestic / international) with different flavors of LTE (FDD and TDD) in addition to multi-band antenna. At the minimum, it must also provide fallback capabilities to either GSM or CDMA (or both), besides having voice network under SIP or VoLTE. I doubt an Icera incorporated T4 SoC can even meet this formidable challenge in time to compete effectively when Qualcomm is already years ahead of this game.

Topic.Title: Gray is dead, long live Gray

Message.Msg: Ibexx, you are behind in technology. Being able to support multiple bands is a question of antenna technology which happens to be the biggest battery drain inside of a smartphone aside from the power-hungry standalone processor (though SoC helps but not nearly as much). Currently, Qualcomm supports 7 bands under its WTR1605L which has now been incorporated into its Snapdragon SoC MSM-8960 using a 28nm implementation. However, today Skycross has just announced a new generation of antenna called VersiTune-LTE that provides 12 bands MIMO simultaneously. “SkyCross has announced their device antenna technology and plans for world domination, which essentially shrinks the total space required for antennae in a device. They put it best…”The SkyCross VersiTune-LTE™ tunable antenna module leverages SkyCross patented ST-iMAT™ technology, enabling a single antenna structure to operate over up to 12 transmit and receive bands while providing optimized MIMO functionality crucial for 4G LTE speeds.”

Topic.Title: Gray is dead, long live Gray

Message.Msg: Ibexx, you are also wrong to suggest that carriers and smartphone makers are opting to support fewer bands. That ship has sailed long ago. Due to the scarcity of spectrum carriers will be required to support as many bands as possible now that the technology exists to amalgamate multiple bands into a single fat pipe through LTE-A Carrier Aggregation. Besides, supporting multiple bands also provide carriers with the ability for roaming both domestically and globally. The smartphones are also heading toward different application categories like using low frequency band for voice and mid-to-high frequency bands for data. The MDM9615 by Qualcomm is the most widely used modem in the world today (Galaxy III, Nokia 950, Iphone 5, etc.) because this Gobi chip inside provides multiple bands and multiple network protocols simultaneously. Under the LTE-Advanced Carrier Aggregation technology any discontiguous bands from a carrier’s own network can be combined even with other carriers (through dynamic spectrum leasing) to provide a single “fat pipe” used in delivering high speed data streaming such as HD videos. In terms of smartphone device makers like Samsung and Apple, they would much prefer to have modem (or through SoC) that can provide multiple bands with the option to activate dynamically by carriers when the need arises. Besides, building a smartphone that can target the entire world markets creates an enormous economy of scale in production costs. As you can see, having the most multiple bands is now a requirement with any smartphones. Nvidia will have to be step ahead to stay viable and to foresee the changing dynamics otherwise Nvidia is heading for obsolescence in just a matter of few years.

Topic.Title: "Project Denver going great!" says Jen Hsun Huang

Message.Msg: One of the more uninformed comments I've seen. Servers will be around as along as there is a need for data. Whether it's for 'cloud server architecture' or the current 'architecture', servers will always be needed with increasing pressure to save on energy costs as well. The very reason you see the changes being considered for cloud based applications is the same reason Nvidia's Project Denver is in an ideal position to take advantage of the changing server market. Desktops are in decline, not servers. Your comments about 'wall-plugged' versus what? No matter how the user receives the data, there will ALWAYS be a need for the data storage (& computing power) somewhere so whatever form the server becomes physically, it will be in demand, and that demand will only increase, not decrease.

Topic.Title: "Project Denver going great!" says Jen Hsun Huang

Message.Msg: There is one pathetic thing worse than a brown nose, it's the sight of a brown tongue such as yourself.

Topic.Title: "Project Denver going great!" says Jen Hsun Huang

Message.Msg: You are being short sighted. Nvidia makes server component (chip) and needs volume sales to become profitable while recuperating its R&D costs of Denver. The cloud servers are being deployed to replace companies’ traditional servers therefore the number of servers that have been traditionally sold in the market will now decline substantially. This is due to server consolidation into the cloud and thereby affecting Nivida sales volume because there will be less servers purchased by companies.

Topic.Title: "Project Denver going great!" says Jen Hsun Huang

Message.Msg: No, you are being short-sighted. Nvidia has been developing chips for both types of servers, whether it's GPU or CPU. They are lined up for ARM based servers AND for cloud servers. In fact, they already have the components for cloud servers in the pipeline. Do your own research on Nvidia, not just the competition.

Topic.Title: "Project Denver going great!" says Jen Hsun Huang

Message.Msg: For cloud based architecture I was referring to the current offerings in GPUs. They aren't seeing Denver as an exclusive core to servers btw. Your comments focus on one segment of computing and Nvidia is focused on a much larger pallette (as are Apple, Samsung and others are . .). Between now and 2015, the computing landscape will be going through several changes and Nvidia has foothold in almost all segments. Also, all the concern about R&D expenses should be taken in perspective with what all the competition is spending and with the knowledge that Nvidia essentially has no debt and continues to add cash, enough to provide a dividend and buyback extension now. Jen wouldn't have gone forward with the dividend and buyback at this stage without knowledge of what's ahead for his forthcoming launches.

Message.Title: Apple and HTC settle global patent battle
Message.Msg: (Reuters) - Apple Inc and HTC Corp announced on Saturday a global patent settlement and 10-year licensing agreement that ends one of the first major conflagrations of the smartphone patent wars. =============== We should expect more HTC devices powered by Tegra. Great news before One X+ arrial.

Message.Title: Nexus 7 Beats iPad on Holiday Wishlists
Message.Msg: The Google Nexus 7 edges out the iPad as this year’s favorite. The survey found that one-third of tablet shoppers plan to pick up the Nexus 7, with nearly 30% opting for an iPad and 24% choosing Apple’s newest release, the iPad Mini. The Microsoft Surface tablet, Kindle Fire and Nook Tablet were the least desired. Source: mashableDOTcom/2012/11/09/nexus-7-ipad-holidays/

Message.Title: VirnetX adds iPhone 5 to new Apple lawsuit after $368m trial win
Message.Msg: Source: guardian.coDOTuk/technology/2012/nov/09/apple-virnetx-patent-iphone-5

Topic.Title: Apple and HTC settle global patent battle

Message.Msg: Apple, HTC Settle Patent Dispute, Sign Licensing Pact By IAN SHERR | Wall Street Journal In excerpts. Apple Inc. and HTC Corp.announced a broad ten-year licensing agreement that settles all of the lawsuits between the companies around the world. More specific terms of the deal were not disclosed. An HTC spokeswoman also declined to provide specifics of the deal but said the company does not expect the license agreement to have an Adverse Material Impact on the company. The broad patent deal comes after HTC suffered several legal setbacks, such as a decision in the U.S. International Trade Commission that said Apple's iPhone and iPad mobile devices had not infringed HTC's patents. In a separate case, the ITC found HTC's phones infringed Apple's patents. In striking the settlement, HTC joins Nokia Corp. as the latest handset maker to have settled litigation with Apple. The settlement comes as Apple has become an epicenter of a global patent war among industry titans, including Samsung Electronics Co. and Google Inc.'s Motorola MSI handset unit. Apple was asked several times to attempt a settlement with Samsung during its high-profile case in a California court several months ago. Heads of both firms held talks, but they were unable to strike a deal. Apple ultimately won the case, with a jury awarding it $1 billion in damages. Samsung said it will appeal that decision. Mr. Cook has expressed interest in settling those cases as well, on conference calls and in interviews, but so far neither Apple or its remaining courtroom opponents have been able to reach agreements. " Nokia Samsung And now HTC The patent infringers are lining up like cattle to pay their iTribute to Apple.
